title: Reliving It Up
material: Reliving It Up “Time of death,” says a doctor on TV, after frantic efforts to get someone’s heart pumping again fail, “5:11 am.” If it were only that simple! Research is increasingly suggesting that death is a complex process, sometimes reversible—sometimes not. Explore the differences between resuscitation and resurrection, then, without getting too dark, discuss with your team: how much of a person’s mind needs to be intact for it to be a good idea to keep them alive—and who should decide? You may also want to explore some historical ideas about what happens after death, including those below: Valhalla | Tartarus | Diyu | Jigoku Nirvana | samsara | happy hunting ground It’s not as convenient as a wardrobe, but tensei stories offer an alternative portal to fantastical worlds: death and reincarnation. Explore this genre and discuss with your team: what are some common themes in these works, and why might they be so popular today? Could ours be the world that someone from another world be reincarnated in and perceive as fantastical? People have searched for ways to live forever—well, basically forever. Today, many fields of scientific research, many spurred on by billionaires, promise that we are on the cusp of finding the answer—or at least a way to extend our lives in unprecedented ways. Explore the following technologies and discuss with your team: would you choose to undergo these treatments if they were available to you? Would it be good for society if people lived for centuries? cryonics | biomechatronics | regenerative medicine | genetic enhancement senolytics | stem cell therapy | reproductive cloning | digital cloning The manga series Frieren: Beyond Journey’s End portrays a 1000-year old elf with one regret: not getting to know her human companions better before they passed away. This is just one story in a long line of literary works exploring immortality and its consequences. Read the examples below, then discuss with your team: why is immortality such an attractive subject for storytellers? What are some common implications of immortality that they explore? William Wordsworth | “Ode: Intimations of Immortality” (1815) Alfred Lord Tennyson | “Tithonus” (1833) Mary Shelley | “The Mortal Immortal” (1833) Ray Bradbury | “Hail and Farewell” (1948) Ursula K. Le Guin | “The Island of the Immortals” (1998) In 2002, researchers in the United States were able to reconstruct the polio virus from scratch—from materials they ordered in the mail. Explore the emerging field of synthetic biology, then discuss with your team: how might advances in this field help you and your loved ones in the future? What does it mean to synthesize a thing, versus simply to make it? And what future applications of synthetic biology can you imagine existing outside the human body? For scientists interested in studying living organisms, they can turn to the UK’s National Collection of Type Cultures, a repository of century-old bacteria samples. Meanwhile, the thawing permafrost in the arctic is exposing pre-historical pathogens—a boon for adventurous virologists but one that raises the concerning possibility of transmission to modern-day humans. Explore with your team: why are so many of these efforts taking place in the arctic? Noah might not have needed an ark if he’d had the Arctic. Stashed away above the Arctic circle, the Svalbard Global Seed Vault is dedicated to preserving seeds from around the world to guard against extinction. Research it and similar efforts, then discuss with your team: how important is the preservation of living samples of today’s species for future generations?

additional-material.name: death is a complex process
additional-material.text:
The article explores the evolving understanding of death, challenging traditional binary notions that define it as a clear-cut event. Instead, it presents death as a process that lacks a definitive point of no return, supported by emerging scientific evidence. Researchers, including Sam Parnia from NYU Langone Health, suggest that the brain and other organs can endure longer periods of oxygen deprivation than previously thought, potentially allowing for revival in certain circumstances. This shift in perspective could have significant implications for medical practices, particularly in resuscitation and organ donation.

Historically, death has been defined by the irreversible cessation of vital functions, primarily the heart and brain. The introduction of CPR in the 1960s marked a pivotal moment in this understanding, allowing for the possibility of reviving individuals after cardiac arrest. This led to the concept of brain death, which has sparked ongoing debates about the criteria for declaring death. Despite advancements, the biological processes underlying death remain complex and not fully understood, prompting further inquiry into the nuances of the dying brain.

Recent studies have revealed surprising findings about brain activity during and after cardiac arrest. Research indicates that the brain may exhibit electrical surges even after oxygen deprivation begins, suggesting a more resilient capacity than previously recognized. For instance, studies involving pigs have demonstrated the restoration of brain functions hours after decapitation, raising questions about the clarity of the life-death boundary. Similar observations in humans have shown intermittent brain activity during CPR, hinting at the potential for consciousness even in critical states.

The implications of these findings are profound, as they could lead to new medical interventions that enhance survival rates for individuals experiencing sudden cardiac events or other life-threatening situations. Understanding the dying process in greater detail may not only improve resuscitation techniques but also expand the criteria for organ donation by extending the timeframe in which organs can be recovered. As research continues, it may reshape societal, ethical, and legal perspectives on death, emphasizing the collective stake in this fundamental aspect of human existence.

additional-material.name: tensei stories
additional-material.text:
The article explores the rising popularity of reincarnation and villainess themes in anime and manga, particularly within the isekai genre, which involves characters being transported to alternate worlds. This trend has led to the emergence of subgenres such as "tensei," where characters die in their original world and are reborn in a new one with their memories intact, and "akuyaku reijo," focusing on characters reincarnated as powerful antagonists. The article highlights the significant volume of works in these categories, with thousands of titles available on popular digital platforms.

A key factor in the popularity of these narratives is their appeal to readers seeking escapism and the opportunity to experience life as a different person. The manga editor interviewed, referred to as Y-san, notes that the protagonists in tensei stories often have minimal backstory, allowing readers to quickly transition into the new world. This structure caters to a desire for transformation and reinvention, resonating with audiences who may feel constrained by their real-world identities.

The article also delves into the appeal of villainess characters, particularly among female readers. Traditionally, shojo manga has favored pure-hearted protagonists rewarded for their goodness. However, the rise of social media has made more complex emotional narratives popular, leading to a shift in character archetypes. Villainesses, who can assert themselves and defy societal expectations, resonate with readers seeking empowerment and agency, particularly in romantic contexts where they can break free from male control.

Lastly, the article touches on the implications for manga artists working within these genres. While the popularity of tensei and villainess stories can lead to financial success, the saturation of similar narratives may hinder individual artists from establishing distinct identities. Y-san emphasizes the importance of creating memorable works that can connect with readers beyond the immediate genre conventions, suggesting that originality remains crucial even in a crowded market.

additional-material.name: so popular today
additional-material.text:
The article **“How Isekai Anime Reflect Modern Society’s Escapism”** by Timothy Blake Donohoo explores why *isekai*—a genre of anime, manga, and light novels centered on characters reincarnated or transported into other worlds—has become both massively popular and heavily criticized. Donohoo argues that the genre’s enduring appeal lies in its **fantasy of starting over**, its deep ties to **video game culture**, and its function as a **modern form of escapism** for audiences navigating disappointment or monotony in real life.

At the heart of *isekai* is **wish fulfillment**. Protagonists are often portrayed as ordinary or unfulfilled individuals—bored salarymen, reclusive gamers, or disillusioned young people—who gain a second chance in a world where their skills or intelligence make them extraordinary. Series like *Overlord* or *Reborn as a Vending Machine, I Now Wander the Dungeon* literalize this transformation, turning the mundane into something heroic or surreal. These stories tap into a universal desire to break from reality’s limitations and reinvent oneself in a world that offers both freedom and recognition.

The genre’s popularity also stems from its **interconnection with video games**, especially role-playing games (RPGs). Many *isekai* borrow the language of “levels,” “quests,” and “guilds,” evoking the sense of progress and achievement that digital games provide. For gamers, such stories mirror familiar experiences of grinding and growth, while for non-gamers they provide an accessible window into virtual worlds. The shared camaraderie of RPG parties and guilds becomes an emotional anchor, reflecting a longing for connection and purpose that contrasts with modern life’s fragmentation.

At a deeper level, Donohoo reads *isekai* as a **mirror of cultural escapism**. Its idealized heroes and heroines—handsome, powerful, and loved—offer audiences a power fantasy that substitutes control and triumph for the anxieties of ordinary existence. The genre’s repetition and formulaic comfort make it the “comfort food” of anime: predictable, soothing, and safe. Yet this simplicity is also its critique—revealing how contemporary viewers seek not challenge but respite from a world defined by stress, alienation, and digital overstimulation. In essence, *isekai* reflects both the exhaustion and the imagination of a generation longing to live somewhere—anywhere—else.

additional-material.name: basically forever
additional-material.text:
The pursuit of immortality has captivated humanity for millennia, with roots tracing back to ancient civilizations. The article explores this enduring quest, beginning with the epic of Gilgamesh, a Mesopotamian king who sought eternal life after the death of his friend Enkidu. Gilgamesh's journey reflects humanity's deep-seated fear of mortality and the desire to transcend it. This narrative sets the stage for a broader examination of how different cultures have approached the concept of immortality, often intertwining it with religious beliefs and philosophical inquiries.

In contemporary times, the quest for immortality has taken on new dimensions, particularly among wealthy individuals like Jeff Bezos and Peter Thiel, who invest in technologies aimed at extending human life. These modern endeavors often focus on scientific advancements, such as genetic engineering and biotechnology, which promise to unlock the secrets of aging and disease. The article highlights how these pursuits are not merely personal ambitions but also reflect societal values regarding health, wealth, and the human condition.

The implications of this ongoing quest for immortality are profound. Ethical considerations arise regarding access to life-extending technologies, potentially exacerbating existing inequalities. The article raises questions about the societal impact of a population that could live significantly longer lives, including the effects on resources, social structures, and the meaning of life itself. As humanity grapples with these challenges, the historical context of the immortality quest serves as a reminder of the complexities involved in seeking to overcome our natural limitations.

Ultimately, the article illustrates that the desire for immortality is a fundamental aspect of the human experience, rooted in both fear and aspiration. It invites readers to reflect on the implications of pursuing eternal life in a world where death has long been an inescapable reality, suggesting that the quest for immortality may reveal more about our values and beliefs than about the possibility of achieving it.

additional-material.name: spurred on by billionaires
additional-material.text:
Dmitry Itskov, a Russian billionaire, has launched the 2045 Initiative, a project aimed at achieving human immortality through technological advancements by the year 2045. This initiative, which began in February 2011, involves collaboration with a team of 30 prominent Russian scientists to develop a series of technologies that would allow for the transfer of human consciousness into artificial forms, specifically through the use of avatars. The plan outlines a phased approach, starting with the creation of remotely controlled robotic avatars and culminating in the development of holographic avatars that could house human consciousness.

The timeline proposed by the 2045 Initiative includes several key milestones: from 2015 to 2020, the focus will be on creating a robotic version of a human body controlled by a brain-computer interface. The subsequent phase, from 2020 to 2025, aims to develop an avatar capable of housing a human brain at the end of life. By 2030 to 2035, the initiative envisions an avatar that can contain an artificial brain, allowing for the transfer of human personality. Finally, between 2040 and 2045, the goal is to produce a fully functional holographic avatar.

In addition to its technological ambitions, the 2045 Initiative has also established a political party named Evolution 2045, which advocates for a global approach to human development focused on scientific progress rather than military competition. Itskov has actively sought funding from wealthy individuals, emphasizing the potential for significant economic benefits from investing in technologies related to cybernetic immortality. He argues that such investments could lead to the creation of a new industry centered on immortality, fundamentally transforming business and society.

The implications of the 2045 Initiative extend beyond mere technological advancements; it proposes a vision of a future where humanity can transcend biological limitations. The initiative suggests that the new form of existence would enhance human capabilities, enabling individuals to withstand extreme conditions and prioritize spiritual self-improvement over conflict. While the initiative promises that the cost of these avatars could eventually be comparable to that of a car, it raises profound ethical and philosophical questions about the nature of life, identity, and the societal impacts of achieving immortality.

additional-material.name: on the cusp
additional-material.text:
The article reports that **Bank of America Merrill Lynch** analysts predict one of the **largest investment frontiers of the coming decade** will be in technologies aimed at **extending human lifespan**, potentially creating a **$600 billion market by 2025**. Analysts **Felix Tran and Haim Israel** identify what they call a “**techmanity revolution**”—the merging of technology and humanity—driven by rapid progress in **genomics, artificial intelligence, data analytics, wearable devices, and advanced biotechnology**. They argue that these innovations could allow people to live **well past 100 years**, not only by extending life but by significantly improving health and vitality.

The report highlights that **medical knowledge is doubling faster than ever**—every 73 days as of 2020, compared to every 3.5 years in 2010—and that **genomic sequencing costs have fallen by more than 99.999% since 2003**, paving the way for widespread adoption of precision medicine. Bank of America groups the longevity opportunity into **five major sub-themes**:

1. **Genomics** – gene editing and sequencing technologies that revolutionize disease prevention and treatment, with companies like *Illumina*, *Agilent*, and *Danaher* leading the field.
2. **Big Data and AI Health** – using machine learning and massive health datasets to advance diagnostics, pathology, and personalized medicine, driven by firms such as *Alphabet*, *Amazon*, and *Apple*.
3. **Future Food** – innovation in nutrition and agricultural gene editing to promote sustainable and healthy living, with players including *Dow DuPont* and *WW International*.
4. **Ammortality** – a term describing technology-enhanced longevity, focusing on wearables, surgical robotics, and preventative care; key companies include *Intuitive Surgical* and *Zimmer*.
5. **Moonshot Medicine** – experimental, breakthrough therapies for diseases like Parkinson’s, cystic fibrosis, and Alzheimer’s, developed by firms such as *Sangamo*, *Vertex Pharmaceuticals*, and *Neurocrine*.

In essence, the report positions the **quest to delay human death** not as science fiction but as a tangible **economic and technological megatrend**, with investors viewing life-extension science as both **a humanitarian pursuit and a financial opportunity**. The intersection of biotechnology, AI, and personalized health could, according to the analysts, redefine what it means to live a “normal” human lifespan within a generation.

additional-material.name: implications of immortality
additional-material.text:
The article "Immortals That Show Us That Death Is The Best Option" by Shaenon K. Garrity explores the often-overlooked downsides of immortality as depicted in various works of fiction. While the concept of eternal life is typically romanticized, Garrity argues that it can lead to a range of unpleasant experiences, from physical decay to emotional isolation. The piece begins by highlighting the gruesome realities of immortality, such as the need for blood in vampire narratives and the constant maintenance required to keep immortal bodies intact, as illustrated in films like "Death Becomes Her."

Garrity further examines the financial implications of immortality, noting that the assumption of accumulating wealth over time is complicated by inflation and identity verification issues. Characters like Charles Forrester from Frederik Pohl’s "The Age of the Pussyfoot" and Hob Gadling from Neil Gaiman’s "Sandman" illustrate the logistical challenges faced by immortals in managing their finances and social identities. The article also touches on the emotional toll of outliving friends and loved ones, leading to a profound sense of loneliness and grief, as seen in Tolkien's elves and other immortal characters.

The social dynamics of immortality are also scrutinized, with Garrity pointing out that interactions with fellow immortals can be fraught with conflict, competition, or simply annoyance. The article references various narratives, including the "Highlander" series and Tom Holt's "Flying Dutch," to illustrate how immortals may find themselves in undesirable company. Additionally, the monotony of eternal life is highlighted, with characters in John Varley’s stories and Douglas Adams’ works experiencing existential boredom that can lead to despair or madness.

Ultimately, Garrity concludes that while immortality may seem appealing, the reality is often filled with challenges that make death a preferable option. The article serves as a cautionary exploration of the concept, suggesting that the allure of eternal life is frequently overshadowed by the burdens it entails. Through a blend of humor and critical analysis, Garrity invites readers to reconsider the implications of living forever, reinforcing the idea that death may indeed be the best option.

additional-material.name: Ode: Intimations of Immortality
additional-material.text:
"Ode: Intimations of Immortality from Recollections of Early Childhood" by William Wordsworth explores the profound connection between childhood and adulthood, emphasizing the loss of innocence and the enduring impact of early experiences on one's perception of life. The poem opens with a nostalgic reflection on the beauty of nature as seen through the eyes of a child, where every element of the natural world is imbued with a sense of divine light and wonder. However, this initial joy is contrasted with the speaker's current state, where the vibrancy of life has faded, leading to a sense of grief over the loss of that "glory."

As the poem progresses, Wordsworth delves into the theme of memory and the transition from childhood to adulthood. He suggests that while the innocence of youth is fleeting, it leaves behind a lasting imprint on the soul. The speaker acknowledges the inevitability of growing up, where the "shades of the prison-house" begin to close around the child, obscuring the light of imagination and joy. Yet, despite this encroaching darkness, there remains a connection to the past, as the speaker reflects on the "trailing clouds of glory" that accompany the soul from its divine origins.

Wordsworth further articulates the tension between the joys of nature and the burdens of adult life. He portrays childhood as a time of unrestrained joy and creativity, where the child is free to engage with the world without the weight of societal expectations. However, as one matures, the responsibilities of life overshadow this innate bliss. The poem suggests that while adulthood brings challenges, it also offers opportunities for deeper understanding and appreciation of life's complexities.

In conclusion, the ode serves as a meditation on the interplay between joy and sorrow, innocence and experience. Wordsworth ultimately finds solace in the enduring power of childhood memories, which can provide comfort and insight throughout life. The poem asserts that even in the face of loss, the beauty of nature and the essence of childhood remain integral to the human experience, offering a source of strength and inspiration.

additional-material.name: Tithonus
additional-material.text:
"Tithonus" is a poem by Alfred Lord Tennyson that explores themes of immortality, aging, and the nature of love. The speaker, Tithonus, is a figure from Greek mythology who was granted eternal life but not eternal youth. This paradox leads him to lament his condition as he witnesses the decay of nature and the passage of time around him. The poem opens with vivid imagery of the natural world in decline, contrasting the inevitable mortality of man and the beauty of youth, which Tithonus can no longer share.

As Tithonus reflects on his existence, he expresses a deep sense of loss and isolation. He recalls his former glory and beauty, which seem to have been overshadowed by his current state as a "white-hair'd shadow." The speaker's desire for immortality, granted with a smile by the goddess Aurora, has turned into a curse. He feels trapped in a world where he is surrounded by eternal youth but is unable to partake in it, leading to a profound sense of longing and despair.

The poem delves into the emotional turmoil of Tithonus as he grapples with his condition. He questions the value of his immortality, pondering why one would wish to deviate from the natural cycle of life and death. His plea to Aurora to take back her gift underscores his desire for release from the burdens of eternal life. The imagery of the "dark world" from which he came serves as a reminder of his mortality and the comfort that comes with it, contrasting sharply with the coldness he feels in his current state.

Ultimately, "Tithonus" encapsulates the tension between the desire for eternal life and the acceptance of mortality. Tithonus's reflections on love, beauty, and the passage of time reveal the complexities of human experience. The poem concludes with a yearning for a return to the earth, suggesting that true fulfillment lies in the natural cycle of life and death, rather than in the unending existence that he now endures.

additional-material.name: The Mortal Immortal
additional-material.text:
"The Mortal Immortal," a short story by Mary Shelley, explores themes of love, ambition, and the nature of immortality through the narrative of Winzy, a young man who becomes entangled in the world of alchemy under the tutelage of the renowned philosopher Cornelius Agrippa. The story begins with Winzy reflecting on his three hundred and twenty-third birthday, questioning whether he is truly immortal. He recounts his past, detailing his love for Bertha, a girl from a humble background who is adopted by a wealthy woman after losing her parents. Their love is tested by social class and the pressures of wealth, leading to Winzy's jealousy and despair as he struggles to secure a future with her.

Winzy's journey takes a pivotal turn when he decides to accept Cornelius's offer of employment, motivated by his desire to win Bertha's affection. As he immerses himself in alchemical studies, he becomes increasingly consumed by jealousy when Bertha appears to favor another suitor, Albert Hoffer. In a moment of desperation, Winzy accidentally consumes a potion meant to cure love, which instead fills him with an intoxicating sense of joy and confidence. This unexpected outcome leads to a rekindling of his relationship with Bertha, culminating in their marriage, as Winzy believes he has been cured of his love for her.

However, the narrative takes a darker turn when Cornelius, on his deathbed, reveals that the potion he had created was intended to grant immortality. Winzy initially embraces this idea, believing he has achieved eternal life. Yet, as time passes, he begins to doubt the validity of Cornelius's claims and reflects on the nature of his existence. He recognizes that while he may have gained longevity and happiness, true immortality remains elusive. The story culminates in Winzy's realization that the effects of the potion are fading, leading him to confront the reality of his mortality.

Ultimately, "The Mortal Immortal" serves as a meditation on the human condition, questioning the desirability of eternal life and the burdens that accompany it. Through Winzy's experiences, Shelley examines the interplay between love, ambition, and the quest for meaning in a life that is both fleeting and filled with longing. The story invites readers to consider the implications of immortality, suggesting that the true essence of life may lie not in its duration but in the depth of human connections and the experiences shared with others.

additional-material.name: The Island of the Immortals
additional-material.text:
"The Island of the Immortals," a short story by Ursula K. Le Guin, explores the themes of immortality, curiosity, and cultural disconnection through the journey of a traveler to a mysterious island. The narrative begins with the protagonist's inquiry about the Island of the Immortals, a place rumored to be inhabited by people who do not die. Despite warnings from a local travel agent about the island's dangers, particularly the presence of flies, the protagonist's curiosity compels them to embark on the journey. The island is depicted as a remote and uninviting destination, lacking tourist facilities and characterized by a sense of decay.

Upon arrival, the traveler learns from historical accounts, particularly that of an explorer named Postwand, that the island's inhabitants are not truly immortal but have a unique relationship with a disease called udreba, which is feared by outsiders. Postwand's account reveals the islanders' dismissive attitude towards mainlanders and their claims of immortality, suggesting a cultural divide between the two groups. The traveler grapples with the implications of immortality, questioning whether the islanders truly possess the secret to eternal life or if their existence is marked by suffering and disease.

As the protagonist interacts with the islanders, they find a community that appears listless and disenchanted, contrasting sharply with the allure of immortality. The young boatman, who initially seems to hold knowledge about the immortals, reveals that there are few, if any, remaining on the island. This conversation highlights the disillusionment surrounding the concept of eternal life, as the islanders do not actively seek immortality, and the protagonist's expectations are met with a stark reality. The story culminates in a reflection on the nature of life, death, and the human desire for longevity, ultimately suggesting that the pursuit of immortality may not lead to fulfillment.

Le Guin's narrative raises profound questions about the value of life and the societal implications of immortality. The island serves as a metaphor for the human condition, illustrating how the quest for eternal life can lead to isolation and despair rather than the joy and vitality that one might expect. Through the protagonist's journey, the story invites readers to consider the complexities of existence and the often-overlooked beauty of mortality.

additional-material.name: materials they ordered in the mail
additional-material.text:
In July 2002, researchers at the State University of New York successfully synthesized a functional polio virus using commercially available chemicals and publicly accessible genetic information. This groundbreaking achievement marked the first instance of a complete virus being created in a laboratory setting from scratch. The team, led by Jeronimo Cello, Aniko Paul, and Eckard Wimmer, utilized harmless DNA fragments ordered through the mail to construct a synthetic version of the polio virus, which was capable of infecting mice and causing illness. This development raised significant concerns among health experts, particularly in light of ongoing global efforts to eradicate polio.

The World Health Organization (WHO) was actively campaigning to eliminate the wild polio virus by 2005, and the news of the synthetic virus creation alarmed specialists in the field. The successful synthesis of polio raised fears that similar techniques could be applied to create more dangerous viruses, such as smallpox, which had previously been considered secure due to its limited existence in only two laboratories worldwide. James LeDuc, a virus specialist at the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, expressed concern over the implications of such research, highlighting the ease with which a virus could be fabricated in a laboratory environment.

The article explains that the genetic code for the polio virus consists of just 7,741 letters, a relatively small sequence that took the researchers two years to assemble chemically. In contrast, the genetic code for smallpox is significantly larger, comprising approximately 185,000 letters. Despite this complexity, experts like Vadim Agol from the Russian Academy of Medical Sciences acknowledged that synthesizing smallpox is theoretically possible, raising ethical and security questions about the potential for bioterrorism.

This incident underscores the thin line between living and non-living entities, as viruses rely on the biological machinery of living organisms to replicate. The ability to create viruses from genetic codes not only poses risks for public health but also challenges existing frameworks for biosecurity and ethical research practices. The implications of such advancements in synthetic biology necessitate careful consideration and regulation to prevent misuse in the future.

additional-material.name: synthetic biology
additional-material.text:
Synthetic biology is an interdisciplinary field that merges principles from engineering and biology to design and construct new biological systems with specific functionalities. The discipline has evolved significantly since its inception in the early 2000s, marked by the creation of synthetic gene circuits such as toggle switches and oscillators in bacterial systems. This rapid advancement has led to applications across various domains, including health, environmental protection, and energy production. The market for synthetic biology is projected to grow substantially, indicating its increasing relevance and potential impact on society.

At the core of synthetic biology is the design-build-test-learn (DBTL) cycle, which facilitates the systematic development of biological systems. Researchers utilize a range of tools and techniques, including genome engineering methods like CRISPR-Cas9, to manipulate genetic material and create novel organisms or biosensors. These engineered systems can perform specific tasks, such as detecting environmental changes or producing valuable compounds. The modularity of synthetic biology allows for the assembly of standardized biological parts, enabling the construction of complex circuits that can function independently or in concert.

The implications of synthetic biology extend beyond mere technological advancements; they also challenge traditional biological explanations. The field advocates for a shift in how biological systems are understood, emphasizing the importance of reproducibility and reconstruction of biological functions as criteria for explanation. This perspective aligns synthetic biology more closely with engineering disciplines, where the ability to replicate and manipulate systems is paramount. As such, synthetic biology is not only reshaping biological research but also influencing broader scientific methodologies.

Despite its promise, synthetic biology faces challenges, including ethical considerations, safety concerns, and regulatory hurdles. As the field continues to grow, it is crucial to address these issues to ensure responsible development and application of synthetic biological systems. The ongoing research and innovation in synthetic biology hold the potential to revolutionize various sectors, but careful oversight and ethical frameworks will be essential to navigate the complexities associated with this rapidly evolving discipline.

additional-material.name: National Collection of Type Cultures
additional-material.text:
The National Collection of Type Cultures (NCTC) was established on January 1, 1920, originating from a sample taken from Private Ernest Cable during World War I. This collection, now one of the oldest living libraries of bacteria, is housed at a UK Health Security Agency (UKHSA) site and serves as a critical resource for scientists globally in understanding infectious diseases. Over its century-long history, the NCTC has survived significant challenges, including World War II and multiple relocations, while continuously expanding its repository of bacterial strains.

Initially located at the Lister Institute of Preventative Medicine, the NCTC began with 200 cultures, primarily deposited by Sir Frederick William Andrewes. The collection was preserved during the war after being moved to a farmhouse, allowing it to continue supporting scientific research. The NCTC has since grown to include approximately 6,000 bacterial strains from over 900 species, focusing on those of clinical and veterinary significance. Notably, the collection includes the Oxford Staphylococcus (NCTC 6571), which played a pivotal role in the development of penicillin.

The methods for sharing bacterial samples have evolved significantly since the NCTC's inception. Early practices involved live cultures transported on agar mediums, posing infection risks to handlers. Today, strains are preserved through freeze-drying, a technique adopted in 1940 that ensures long-term viability and purity. New strains undergo rigorous examination and quality checks before being added to the collection, maintaining the integrity of the original characteristics.

In recent years, the NCTC has embraced modern genomic technologies, notably sequencing over 3,000 strains between 2013 and 2018 in collaboration with the Wellcome Sanger Institute. This genomic data is publicly accessible, enabling ongoing research into antimicrobial resistance and other health challenges. The NCTC continues to innovate by leveraging new communication technologies and fostering global collaborations, ensuring its relevance and utility in addressing 21st-century health issues as it enters its second century.

additional-material.name: pre-historical pathogens
additional-material.text:
The article discusses the potential risks associated with the thawing of permafrost due to climate change, particularly the re-emergence of ancient viruses and bacteria. As global temperatures rise, permafrost, which has preserved organic material for thousands of years, is beginning to melt. This process not only releases greenhouse gases like carbon dioxide and methane but also raises concerns about pathogens that could pose health risks to humans and wildlife. Researchers emphasize that the melting permafrost could lead to the revival of long-dormant microorganisms, some of which may be harmful.

Evidence from scientific studies indicates that permafrost contains a diverse array of microorganisms, including viruses that have been frozen for millennia. For instance, a study highlighted the discovery of a 30,000-year-old virus that was successfully revived in a laboratory setting. While the likelihood of these ancient pathogens causing widespread outbreaks is uncertain, the potential for new diseases to emerge is a significant concern for public health experts. The article notes that the risk is compounded by the fact that many of these pathogens may not have modern counterparts, making it difficult for current medical science to address them.

The implications of these findings are profound, as they suggest that climate change could not only exacerbate existing health issues but also introduce entirely new threats. The article calls for increased research into the pathogens preserved in permafrost, as well as the development of strategies to monitor and mitigate potential outbreaks. Experts advocate for a proactive approach to understanding the risks associated with thawing permafrost, emphasizing the need for global cooperation in addressing climate change and its multifaceted impacts.

In conclusion, the thawing of permafrost presents a dual challenge: it contributes to climate change while simultaneously posing a potential public health risk through the revival of ancient pathogens. The article underscores the urgency of addressing these interconnected issues, highlighting the importance of scientific research and international collaboration in safeguarding public health in the face of a changing climate.

additional-material.name: Global Seed Vault
additional-material.text:
The Svalbard Global Seed Vault, located in Norway, serves as a crucial resource for preserving the genetic diversity of the world's crops, particularly in the context of climate change. Established in 2008, the vault is designed to safeguard seeds from various global threats, including natural disasters, war, and climate-related challenges. As climate change intensifies, the importance of this facility has grown, as it provides a backup for seed banks worldwide, ensuring that agricultural biodiversity can be maintained and restored when needed.

The article discusses the vault's role in addressing the challenges posed by climate change, which threatens food security through extreme weather events and shifting agricultural zones. The Svalbard Seed Vault acts as a repository for seeds from diverse climates and regions, allowing for the preservation of varieties that may be lost due to changing environmental conditions. This genetic reservoir is vital for future breeding programs aimed at developing crops that can withstand new climate realities, thus supporting global food systems.

Evidence of the vault's significance is highlighted by its recent use, where seeds have been withdrawn to restore collections affected by climate-related disasters. The article emphasizes that the vault is not merely a storage facility but a proactive measure to ensure agricultural resilience. It underscores the collaborative efforts among nations to contribute to the vault, reflecting a shared commitment to global food security and biodiversity conservation.

In conclusion, the Svalbard Global Seed Vault represents a critical strategy in the fight against the impacts of climate change on agriculture. Its existence allows for the preservation of genetic diversity essential for adapting to future challenges, thereby playing a pivotal role in ensuring food security for generations to come. The ongoing support and utilization of the vault underscore the need for international cooperation in addressing the global implications of climate change on agriculture.

additional-material.name: similar efforts
additional-material.text:
Oreo has established a "Doomsday Vault" in Norway, situated near the Svalbard Global Seed Vault, which serves as a safeguard for its iconic cookie recipe and a stockpile of cookies. This initiative reflects a humorous yet serious approach to ensuring the longevity of one of the world's best-selling snacks in the event of catastrophic events. The vault is described as significantly smaller than its seed counterpart and is intended to protect the Oreo recipe and cookies from potential future threats.

The vault's construction was announced alongside a playful marketing campaign, which includes videos featuring actors portraying Oreo executives. Despite the lighthearted tone, the company has taken practical measures to ensure the cookies' preservation. Each cookie pack is wrapped in mylar, a material that can withstand extreme temperatures and is resistant to moisture and air, thereby maintaining freshness for an extended period.

The motivation behind this vault stems from a real but minimal threat posed by asteroids, highlighted by a recent NASA announcement regarding a small asteroid with a slight chance of entering Earth's atmosphere. While the asteroid was deemed harmless, Oreo's decision to create the vault underscores a proactive stance on disaster preparedness, albeit in a whimsical context.

Overall, the Global Oreo Vault serves as a unique marketing strategy that combines humor with a genuine commitment to product preservation. It emphasizes the brand's cultural significance and the lengths to which companies might go to protect their legacy, even in a tongue-in-cheek manner.
